docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13); 10 P.M. (49) MY FATHER, MY BROTHER AND ME In a new episode of ''Frontline,'' the journalist David Iverson, who has Parkinson's disease, explores this degenerative muscular disorder, which affects one million Americans, including his own father and brother, and is prominent in the political and ethical debate surrounding stem cell research. Mr. Iverson (above with his father in 1949) interviews his family members, as well as the actor Michael J. Fox and the writer Michael Kinsley, who both have the condition. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWScarlett Johansson talks about her latest film, ''He's Just Not That Into You.'' Another segment looks at dressing to appear thinner so that in real life ''he'' might be persuaded to change his mind.

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline.main: Mom, Dad, It's Not as Bad as You Think

docs.abstract: In this lesson students will explore how a public perception may differ from reality by examining statistics on teen sexuality and then conducting polls for different demographics to support or refute their findings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two programs for the poor that urgently need federal funding— legal services and access to family planning — were stripped from the House economic package.
